content: How can I help you today?

I'm struggling to be present and focused lately. There’s a lot going on at home with my wife and kids, and it’s overwhelming. My younger son is having serious behavioral issues, and it's putting a strain on everything, especially my marriage. I don’t even know where to start.

That sounds like a difficult and overwhelming situation, with a lot weighing on your mind and heart. Balancing challenges with your son, your marriage, and everything else can be incredibly tough. How have you been managing all of this so far?

Honestly, I don’t feel like I’ve been managing it at all. It feels like I’m just barely getting through each day. I’ve tried to help my son, but nothing seems to work, and it’s just creating more tension with my wife. I feel stuck.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy load and feeling stuck between trying to help your son, manage the tension in your marriage, and take care of yourself at the same time. That’s a lot for anyone to handle. What do you wish things could look like right now for your family or for yourself?

I just want things to feel normal again. I want my son to get the help he needs so he can stop struggling, and I want my wife and I to feel like a team again. It feels like everything's falling apart, and I just want to hold my family together.

You’re clearly deeply committed to your family and want what’s best for everyone—a sense of calm, teamwork, and healing for your son and your marriage. Holding everything together when it feels like it’s falling apart can be exhausting. What gives you hope or strength to keep moving forward right now?

Honestly, it's my family. Even with everything going on, I care so much about them. I don’t want to fail them, and that’s what keeps me trying—though, most days, it doesn’t feel like I’m getting anywhere.

Your dedication to your family is really powerful, even during the toughest moments. It’s clear how much they mean to you and how deeply you value them. It's understandable that feeling like your efforts aren’t bringing progress can be discouraging. What do you think might help you feel even a little less stuck or overwhelmed right now?
I’m not really sure what would help, to be honest. Maybe finding a way to handle everything without feeling this constant pressure. But I don’t even know where to begin with that.

It makes sense that the constant pressure feels like too much—and finding a way to ease that could be a step forward. You're already reflecting on what feels overwhelming, which shows a lot of self-awareness. What’s one small thing you’d like to feel more in control of, whether it’s with your family or just for yourself?

I guess I’d like to feel more in control of how I handle things with my son. It’s like no matter what I try, nothing helps, and it just makes me feel like I’m failing him. If I could figure out how to actually help him, maybe some of the stress would ease up.

It sounds like helping your son is really important to you, and not feeling like your efforts are making a difference has been really challenging. That’s a tough place to be, especially when you care so much. What have you tried so far, and are there approaches you’re curious about or would like to explore?

We’ve tried talking to him, setting boundaries, and offering rewards for good behavior, but nothing seems to stick. It’s like his outbursts and struggles just keep spiraling. I don't even know what could work at this point, but I guess exploring other approaches couldn’t hurt.

It sounds like you’ve been really proactive in trying different methods to support your son, even when it feels like nothing is sticking. That shows how committed you are to helping him. Exploring other approaches could give you fresh ideas or perspectives. Would you be open to considering resources or support—either for him, or for you and your wife—to make this path feel less isolating and overwhelming?

I don't know... I’m not sure how much those kinds of resources could actually help, and I don’t want to overwhelm things even more. But maybe it’s worth considering if it could ease some of the pressure and help us figure out how to move forward.

It’s understandable to feel unsure about adding more to an already overwhelming situation. At the same time, it’s thoughtful that you’re open to considering something that might reduce the strain and provide new ways to move forward. Is there anything else you’d like to talk through before exploring that possibility?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
